title-group.article-title: Addition–subtraction osteotomy with ligamentoplasty for symptomatic trapezial dysplasia with metacarpal instability

abstract.p: Trapeziometacarpal instability with trapezial dysplasia is a disabling condition long before the radiological changes of osteoarthritis appear. In dysplastic joints surgical soft tissue correction fails to prevent the instability, requiring a correction of the bony anatomy. We combined two techniques described in the past, an abduction osteotomy of the first metacarpal and an opening wedge osteotomy of the trapezium, to which we added a ligament reconstruction. The combination of both osteotomy techniques restores the anatomy and centres the forces acting across the joint. We have done this procedure 21 times since 2003 in 18 patients. Seventeen thumbs were reviewed prospectively with a mean follow-up of 39 (range 16–65) months. Mean QuickDASH improved by 33.9 points, the key pinch improved by 1.8 kg and the grip strength improved by 8.7 kg. The visual analogue scale for pain improved from 7.9 preoperatively to 2 postoperatively. This technique preserves the trapeziometacarpal joint, allowing other techniques to be used if painful arthritis should develop in the middle to long term.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Instability of the trapeziometacarpal joint due to dysplasia of the trapezium is difficult to treat. The patients are young, mostly female and have high demands. Pain is induced by thumb to finger pinch. The quality of the cartilage is often good and soft tissue stabilization with ligamentoplasties (Brunelli et al., 1989; Eaton and Littler, 1973; Glickel and Gupta, 2006) or abductor pollicis longus tenotomies (Zancolli, 2001) do not guarantee good relief of pain since the fundamental problem is of bony origin: the dysplasia of the trapezium and its increased articular slope (Bahri et al., 1982; Bettinger et al., 2001; Kapandji, 1990; Kapandji and Heim, 2002; Rongières, 2004). Various osteotomies have been suggested (Holmberg and Lundborg, 1996; Kapandji and Heim, 2002; Messina, 2000; Roux, 2004; Wilson, 1973; Wilson and Bossley, 1983). Wilson (1973) described a technique for the treatment of osteoarthritis with an osteotomy at the base of the thumb metacarpal. The goal of this technique was to correct the adduction deformity (Wilson, 1973; Wilson and Bossley, 1983). Kapandji and Heim (2002) described a reorientation osteotomy of the trapezial saddle; this technique corrects the articular slope of the dysplastic trapezium. The Wilson osteotomy cannot correct the subluxation due to the increased trapezial slope when there is trapezial dysplasia. We report the use of a double osteotomy to reposition the trapeziometacarpal joint by correcting the axis (subtraction) of the thumb metacarpal and the trapezial dysplasia (addition) simultaneously. The goal of this technique was to correct the adduction deformity and correct the articular slope of the dysplastic trapezium. With the combination of both techniques, the morbidity of an extra donor site is avoided by placing the removed subtraction graft of the thumb metacarpal into the osteotomy of the trapezium. A ligamentoplasty using the half of the flexor carpi radialis tendon as a lasso around the base of the thumb metacarpal to correct the chronic laxity was added after carrying out the osteotomy (Goubau et al., 2007).

This combined technique of double osteotomy together with the ligament reconstruction corrects the dysplastic anatomy, centres forces across the axis of the joint and stabilizes the stretched ligaments. We report the results of 21 cases operated on between 2003 and 2007.

sec.title: Patients and methods
sec.p: Eighteen patients (21 joints) were treated surgically for primary instability of the trapeziometacarpal joint due to dysplasia of the trapezium in our department between 2003 and 2007. The patients complained of thumb pain at rest and/or during light activities. This persisted despite conservative treatment, which consisted of night splinting and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory medication. The indication for surgery was instability of the trapeziometacarpal joint due to dysplasia of the trapezium with secondarily an unstable base of the thumb metacarpal and a well preserved joint space on the radiographs. Preoperative radiographs included frontal and profile views as described by Kapandji (Kapandji and Kapandji, 1993; Kapandji et al., 1980). The radiographs taken showed a clear instability of the base of the thumb metacarpal on the Eaton view with stress testing (Figure 1A). The same radiograph was taken with and without radial stress testing of the distal radial part of the thumb. An increase in subluxation of the base of the thumb metacarpal combined with dysplasia of the trapezium was diagnosed as instability. This test explicitly reproduced the pain the patients complained about at the base of the thumb. All patients, except one, had an increased Dévers’ angle (Kapandji and Heim, 2002); this is the angle measured between the axis of the second metacarpal and the slope of the trapezium (normal angle is 129° with 6° of range). The angle is measured on radiograph in the frontal view described by Kapandji (Kapandji and Heim, 2002; Kapandji et al., 1980) (Figure 2). The angle tends to increase with increasing dysplasia of the trapezium. A double (addition–subtraction) osteotomy was done in the patients (Figure 3A). The required angular correction was measured preoperatively, and the size of the wedge was measured in order to obtain a normal Dévers’ angle. The limit of the angular correction is the size of the short side of the wedge taken from the base of the thumb metacarpal, usually between 3 mm and 4 mm; it should not exceed 5 mm to avoid an overcorrection deformity of the axis of the thumb metacarpal. In this prospective study we carried out a ligamentoplasty in all patients after the osteotomy using a strip of half of the flexor carpi radialis tendon (Figure 3B).

sec.title: Operative technique
sec.p: The proximal part of the first metacarpal and trapeziometacarpal joint is exposed by a proximally extended anterolateral Gedda and Moberg (1953) incision (2 cm proximal to the distal palmar wrist crease). Then the abductor pollicis longus (APL) slip to the opponens is disinserted, making sure to retain a tendinous slip on the opponens. The opponens and APL origin are dissected from the anterior side of the trapeziometacarpal joint, making sure to preserve the articular capsule. The location of the flexor carpi radialis (FCR) tendon is now determined at the ulnar side of the trapezium followed by removal of the periosteum of the proximal third of the thumb metacarpal, making sure to preserve the integrity of the articular capsule of the trapeziometacarpal (TM) joint. A longitudinal incision is made in the joint capsule allowing inspection of the quality of the TM cartilage.

Using the guidance of the image intensifier, the level of the osteotomy is chosen (Figure 2). Care is taken to perform this osteotomy in the metaphyseal region to enhance rapid consolidation. An osteotomy parallel to the articular surface is made approximately 8 mm distal to the TM joint. This is done with a small oscillating saw. To facilitate this, a needle is inserted into the joint parallel to the base of the thumb metacarpal. Care is taken not to cut the whole diameter of the metaphysis. The distal level of the osteotomy is determined by making an inclined cut producing a wedge with its base on the radial/dorsal border of the thumb metacarpal, which is slightly larger dorsally and radially to create an antepulsion effect. The size of the base of the wedge is calculated by measuring the amount of slope of the trapezium that has to be corrected to regain a normal slope. The size of the wedge will not exceed 4 to 5 mm at its base, and will have an apical angle between 15° and 25°. Ideally, an ulnar hinge is preserved to create a stable closure of the osteotomy after removal of the wedge. Both surfaces are firmly pressed against each other and maintained with two Kirschner wires of 1.2 mm diameter. The position is verified under image intensifier.

Under image intensifier control in a frontal view of the trapezium, the middle of the waist of the body of the trapezium is located (Figure 2). A needle can be inserted into the scapho-trapezoid-trapezial space (STT) and TM joint to allow better localization of the osteotomy site. Under image intensifier guidance, the osteotomy is made with an oscillating saw parallel to the articular surface of the trapezium, using the intra-articular needle as a guide. When 70% of the width of the trapezium has been cut, making sure not to lacerate the FCR tendon, a thin chisel of 1 cm width is inserted to finish the osteotomy, which allows the preservation of an ulnar hinge. The osteotomy through the trapezium is opened by hinging the almost completely inserted chisel on the ulnar fulcrum. The resected metacarpal wedge is inserted along this chisel into the gap and held in place in press-fit after removal of the chisel (Figure 3A). Care is taken to position the base of the wedge flush with the radial border of the trapezium. No osteosynthesis is necessary at the level of the trapezium, since the compression is done naturally by the hinge in a press-fit fashion (Figure 4). Finally a FCR tendinoplasty is lassoed around the base of the thumb metacarpal and sutured on itself in Pulvertaft fashion to stabilize the chronic ligamentous laxity of the anterior oblique, intermetacarpal and palmar ligaments (Figure 3B).

sec.title: Postoperative care
sec.p: A forearm cast including the thumb with opening of the thumb web and in opposition is applied for 6 weeks. A thumb splint is kept for another 3 weeks at night. No further rehabilitation is prescribed. Patients are seen the day after the operation, after 2 weeks, 5 weeks, 8 weeks and 3 months after operation. The K-wires are removed after 3 months when necessary, after which patients can resume heavy manual activities.

sec.title: Assessment
sec.p: Eighteen patients, 17 female, with a mean age of 45.2 (range 22–58) years were treated surgically after failure of conservative treatment. Fifteen cases were unilateral and three bilateral.
Patients were assessed for mobility, strength, pain, function, appearance and satisfaction. Radiographs were evaluated preoperatively and postoperatively.

The mobility of the thumb in opposition (1–10) and retropulsion (1–3) was graded as described by Kapandji (1990). Strength was measured before and after operation using a calibrated hydraulic pinch gauge and a calibrated hydraulic hand dynamometer (Baseline Fabrication Enterprises Inc., New York, USA). Pain was scored with the 0–10 visual analogue scale (VAS) (0 = no pain, 10 = severe pain). Function was assessed by the QuickDASH score. Opposition and retropulsion were recorded by the method of Kapandji (1990). Dévers’ angle was measured on frontal radiographs before and after operation.

Descriptive and inferential statistical techniques were applied to the data. Normally distributed data were analysed pre- and postoperatively using the paired Student’s t-test, whilst data that did not exhibit normality were tested for significance using the non-parametric Wilcoxon Signed Ranks matched pairs test. Normality was tested first by graphing the data and then confirmed using the Kolmogorov Smirnov assumption test. Statistical significance was accepted at the level of p ≤ 0.05.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: In this study we reviewed 15 patients (17 joints) prospectively. Three patients were lost to follow-up. Out of the reviewed patients, two underwent bilateral and 13 patients unilateral surgery. Surgery was done in eight dominant and nine non-dominant hands. The patients had a mean follow-up of 39 (range 16–65) months postoperatively.
The results for changes in grip strength, radiographic parameters, function and ROM are shown in Table 1. Several of the measured parameters revealed significant improvements postoperatively.

sec.p: Key pinch improved on average by 1.79 (range 5.3–7.1) kg, power grasp improved by 8.7 (range 22.9–31.6) kg.

The VAS for pain changed from a mean value of 7.9 (SD 0.7) before operation to a mean of 2 (SD 2.8) at final follow-up. Only three of the 15 patients used painkillers at the time of review. Eighty percent had a good result (VAS of 3 or less) postoperatively.

All patients were highly satisfied with the appearance of the incision. Subjective satisfaction was high and 13 of the 15 patients (14 out of 17 joints) would have the operation again. The changes in the QuickDASH results and Dévers angle were highly significant (p < 0.0001).

Two patients presented with persistent pain related to osteoarthritis. One of these had a prosthetic trapeziometacarpal replacement 16 months after the osteotomy. One patient had to be operated on twice more for pseudarthrosis due to entrapment of the ligament reconstruction into the osteotomy. In no case was there damage to the articular surface due to an iatrogenic fracture or other perforation into the joint.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Trapeziometacarpal joint pain is common among women of relatively young age and is often associated with a dynamic adduction deformity of the thumb metacarpal, combined with radial subluxation at the base of the thumb metacarpal. The period of time between the onset of symptoms and eventual irreversible degenerative changes can last for many years. Techniques that are applicable for arthritic joints in young patients, such as fusion or prosthetic replacement (Alberts and Engkvist, 1989; Stark et al., 1977; Swanson et al., 1981) cannot be used in painful but healthy unstable dysplastic joints.

These joints have a significant dysplasia of the trapezium with a hypoplastic lateral rim, causing an instability and subluxation at the base of the thumb metacarpal. This laxity is due to the elongation of the anterior oblique superficial and deep ligaments (Rongières, 2004), which causes progressive pain with repetitive mechanical load. This mechanism progressively damages parts of the articular surface of the joint. The onset is localized to the anteroulnar border of the thumb metacarpal base and at the anteroradial border of the trapezial saddle.

Symptomatic patients presenting with an increased slope of the trapezium combined with a clear instability of the base of the thumb metacarpal (increased dynamic subluxation of the base of the thumb metacarpal in Eaton view with stress testing of both thumbs against each other) should be treated at both trapezial and metacarpal levels in order to centre forces towards the middle of the joint. An opening trapezial wedge osteotomy (addition) corrects the dysplasia of the trapezium but fails to restore the centring forces on the thumb metacarpal. An extension osteotomy (subtraction) realigns the thumb metacarpal by unloading the palmar contact areas and hence restores the anatomical alignment of the unstable metacarpal base (Pellegrini et al., 1996). Both osteotomies are essential for correction of the instability. The added ligamentoplasty provides stabilization for the chronically stretched ligaments of the trapeziometacarpal joint. In this study it was done in all patients as part of the surgical procedure.

A well preserved articular cartilage is mandatory to obtain the best results. In this study, the bad results occurred when chronic instability had damaged the joint cartilage too much to prevent further deterioration after the osteotomy and ligamentoplasty. If there is any doubt about the state of the cartilage, CT or arthroscopy of the trapeziometacarpal joint should be done to avoid surgery that will be ineffective.

There are other surgical techniques that preserve the joint surfaces. The increased trapezial slope in early osteoarthritis of the trapeziometacarpal joint has been poorly described (Ropars et al., 2009). Kapandji and Heim (2002) reported on seven cases with seven good results after reorientation osteotomy of the trapezial saddle in cases with a pathological slope of the trapezial saddle and either no or very slight arthritis. Ropars et al. (2009) have reported the results of experimental trapezial osteotomy with its technically demanding aspects and the possible complications.

Vascularized rotation osteotomies have been described in which the trapeziometacarpal joint is turned 180° to correct the pathological slope of the trapezium and subluxation of the base of the thumb metacarpal in one movement (Roux, 2003; 2004). A vascularized rotation osteotomy of the trapezoid–trapezium complex, which has been described for severe trapeziometacarpal arthritis, can also be used when there is an unstable base of the thumb metacarpal and trapezial dysplasia (Messina, 2000).

Metacarpal osteotomies have been reported widely. Treatment of early stage trapeziometacarpal joint arthritis by extension osteotomy of the thumb compensates for the incompetence of the anterior oblique ligament and reduces the laxity in the dorsal–palmar direction. Extension osteotomy of 30° gave more than 90% good results in terms of pain relief and improved grip and pinch strength at 2 years follow-up (Tomaino, 2000). Long term results confirm its ongoing effectiveness (Parker et al., 2008). However, extension osteotomy alone does not address the increased trapezial slope (Kapandji and Heim, 2002).

Ligament reconstruction has been reported in treatment of the pre-arthritic trapeziometacarpal joint (Van Giffen et al., 2002). In the early stages of degenerative arthritis the overall outcome was good with a mean DASH score of 23.2. The trapeziometacarpal joint was stable, but a 43% progression of radiographic osteoarthritic deterioration occurred. In this study there was no mention of the Dévers’ angle or trapezial tilt (Bettinger et al., 2001). Experimental studies have shown that ligament reconstruction by the method of Eaton and Littler (1973) and extension osteotomy both reduce dorso-palmar laxity (Koff et al., 2006). The Eaton and Littler procedure was not associated with recognizable degeneration in Stage I patients or in 82% of stage II patients up to 13 years postoperatively (Eaton et al., 1984).

The value of an additional ligament reconstruction in double osteotomy has to be validated. Most recently we have not done the ligamentoplasty. The early results seem to be similar to those we have obtained with the ligamentoplasty and this may confirm what has been reported experimentally (Koff et al., 2006).

We believe that the addition–subtraction osteotomy has less morbidity than the more complex vascularized articular osteotomies which have similar biomechanical outcomes (Messina, 2000; Roux, 2003; 2004) or the trapezial opening wedge procedure described by Kapandji and Heim (2002) which tends to close the first web. The more than 80% good results that we report in this series indicate the reliability of the technique in the medium term. However a longer follow-up is necessary to determine subjective and radiological outcomes.
This technique does allow the use of other non-joint preserving operative techniques if the procedure is not successful in the longer term.
